title: What is the best laptop with the most reasonable price? - Quora

response.answer_text: tl;dr: consider the Dell XPS 13, Dell Latitude 7490, or any of the Lenovo T-series machines. “Best laptop” depends entirely on your needs (/wants.) Anyone who says there is a single one-size fits all best laptop doesn’t know what they’re talking about. At the extremes, there are machines that are VERY highly optimized for portability (e.g. the Macbook 12″ and similar PC ultraportables) and there are machines optimized for gaming/coding/etc which are much heavier (and usually have large screens.) Someone for whom one or the other of those would be “best” would likely be extremely unhappy with the other — and there definitely are people for whom “best” qualifies as one or the other. “Reasonably priced” is also relative to what you needs/want, and how much you can afford. Even if we ask the more “the best inexpensive laptop for general use,” we’re still going to get into very different definitions of “inexpensive,” some different definitions of “general use,” and different preferences in things like screen size, keyboard style, and the religious war over Mac vs. PC (and whether a Chromebook counts as a laptop, or for that matter whether something like an Android tablet or iPad Pro with a keyboard counts as a laptop.) Moreover, laptop models change over relatively quickly (typically a major new version of ongoing model lines about once a year when Intel updates its processors, and often a mid-year refresh, and on the PC side consumer models sometimes come and go quicker than that) so any specific laptop recommendation is going to get old fast. That said, at a very high level, a couple of short recommendations:* The sweet spot for price/readability/portability is pretty much 13″ size machines these days, whether you’re looking at a PC, a Mac, or a Chromebook. Going to a 14″ or 15″ machine on a consumer PC (not Mac) will generally save you a little money, at the expense of a bigger, heavier machine. 14″ business machines tend to also be a bit of a happy medium — the Dell Latitude 14″ and the Lenovo T480 for example. * How powerful a machine qualifies as “good enough” is very dependent on your use, but in general except for Chromebooks I’d recommend looking for a quad-core (8th generation) i5 if you can afford it — on the Mac side, that basically means you’re looking at the Macbook Pro 13″, which is pricey, and you’re going to have a lot more affordable options on the PC side. * In terms of quality, a lot will depend on whether you want to optimize for appearance (in which case a slimmer ultrabook is better) or for durability (in which case a thicker business machine like a Dell Latitude or Lenovo Thinkpad T-series will be better) … or you can get a lower-end consumer machine to save money, which will be neither particularly thin NOR particularly durable.
